comment:
This game absolutely blew my mind with its creative freedom. I will say In advance that I disagree in a way with the statement that it‚Äôs playable without playing the previous title. Sure, you absolutely can, but it does not hit the same way. My advice, take it or leave it, is to not only play Alan Wake and DLCs, but also play control and DLCs before jumping in. There are things in Alan wake 2 that are directly linked to both titles. Now, you can skip the Xbox exclusive which its name is escaping me at the moment, but I highly highly recommend playing the others. At the end of the day, Alan Wake 2 delivers some of the most creative story telling in the history of video games, absolutely captivating and addictive. The battle mechanics are well thought out and fluid . I did at times find the reload times difficult to navigate depending on the weapon.

The graphics are the best ever seen in a video game and this is in part due to remedies proprietary engine. Their engine is so effective and beautiful that I decided to purchase stock in remedy. I feel that at some point it could take podium where unreal engine has. All in all, if you are a fan of survival, horror, immersive, and disturbing atmospheres, unique, storylines, and are an open minded person, you might find this to be one of the best video games you‚Äôve ever played.

title: Alan Wake 2 - Before You Buy
author: @HoroJoga
comment:
Good sequel, but the storytelling could be a BIT less convoluted. Saga's mind place should be a little more automatized, since it adds little to the gameplay experience and in the end, just repeats what we see by playing the game. There's no feeling of satisfaction in 'deducting' the scenes, so it feels a little dull.
Combat is good in her parts, but Alan's chapters are kinda confusing. The whole 'scene change' gimmick didn't hit as good as Remedy expected to, leaving the player without knowing what plot should he use in each scene -- or if he should try every available plot in his disposal.
The ending is anti-climatic to say the least, and the real final boss fight is earlier in the game, since the ending is just more investigation and a final cutscene.
I'm leaning towards the thought that the story should've had a concrete ending, and leaving it open for a Part 3 doesn't seem very wise and not really honest toward an audience that already waited 13 years for the sequel.
I enjoyed for what it was, and there are plenty of good moments. A solid 7/10.

comment:
I might be on the controversial, but over all i prefered the first game.
Alan wake 2's gameplay and graphics are awesome, story took some interesting and twisting turns here and there, and most of the music is freaking awesome.
Loved the mix between Detective and Writer segments.
But i feel some things were off here and there.

Saga felt too "perfect" as a character.
She has a loving husband and child, she has a rising career without obstacles, she doesn't have any "inner demons"/flaws, she is qualified to examine bodies classified as evidence and also repair out of the ordinary electronic stuff, and could get out of 'that place' she gets locked in without any help.
Alan has been locked in a similar place for years, without succes of escaping.
Could at least get some assist from her mother or grandfather.
Also annoyed they had to go with the 'a white man' near the end, instead of just 'some dumbass writer'. 
We learn she has some family stuff that she didn't know about,  but that doesn't really affect her as a character.
Alan got way too many items in contrast to Saga.
Had tons of health items as Alan, but just enough as Saga.
The buffs are locked for specific attributes, whice honestly kinda annoyed me.

Ending of game, there is no feeling of accomplishment, as your only left with questions, and no answers.
In first game alice gets freed by alan and he sacrifices his freedom for her's.
We don't get any accomplishment in this game.
Have a feeling we will see a DLC in the future, to tie up some loose ends.
The truth of 'the Cult of the tree' felt like a forced obstacle.
I preferred more how the flashlight was toggle controlled in the previous game as well.
First boss kinda felt like a fight from Dark souls, with terrible environment to dodge in.

On the PS5 version, there were a couple of bugs.
One or two required to load to fix it, and the last weapon case for Saga showed it was open, even though i hadn't solved it yet, as i tried to solve the lock, i was unsure if i had solved it and it was bugged, or i was just messing up.
